title: How to Download to an SD Card on Android

steps.title: Open the Files by Google app.
steps.content: Open the Files by Google app. It has an icon that resembles a blue folder with red, green, and yellow pages in the middle. Tap the icon in your Apps menu to open Files by Google.

steps.title: Tap the More menu ☰.
steps.content: Tap the More menu ☰ . It's the button with three horizontal lines in the upper-left corner. This displays the More menu. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Tap Settings.
steps.content: Tap Settings . It's near the top of the More menu. It's next to an icon that resembles a gear.

steps.title: Scroll down and tap the toggle switch next to "Save to SD Card."
steps.content: Scroll down and tap the toggle switch next to "Save to SD Card." It's near the bottom of the Settings menu. This enables saving to the SD card.

steps.title: Tap Continue.
steps.content: Tap Continue . This screen informs you that you need to grant Files access to your SD card.

steps.title: Tap Allow Access to SD Card.
steps.content: Tap Allow Access to SD Card . It's the blue button at the bottom of the screen. This displays a prompt asking you to allow Files to access your SD card.

steps.title: Tap Allow.
steps.content: Tap Allow . This grants Files access to your SD card and allows you to save files to your SD card. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Open the Files by Google app.
steps.content: Open the Files by Google app. It has an icon that resembles a blue folder with red, green, and yellow pages inside. Tap the icon to open Files by Google.

steps.title: Tap Browse.
steps.content: Tap Browse . It's the middle tab at the bottom of the screen. It has an icon that resembles a folder and a magnifying glass.

steps.title: Tap Internal Storage.
steps.content: Tap Internal Storage . It's near the bottom of the menu below "Storage Devices". This displays files on your phone or tablet's internal storage.

steps.title: Tap a category.
steps.content: Tap a category. Files are organized by Image, Video, Audio, Documents, Podcasts, and more. Tap whichever category the file you want to transfer falls under.

steps.title: Tap the three dots next to the file you want to transfer.
steps.content: Tap the three dots next to the file you want to transfer. Tapping the three dots next to a file displays a menu.

steps.title: Tap Select.
steps.content: Tap Select . It's in the menu that appears when you tap the three dots. This displays a blank circle next to all the files, which allows you to select multiple files.

steps.title: Check all the files you want to transfer.
steps.content: Check all the files you want to transfer. To place a checkmark next to a file, tap the circle icon next to the file. Check all files you want to transfer. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Tap the More menu button ⋮.
steps.content: Tap the More menu button ⋮ . It's the icon that has three vertical dots in the upper-right corner. Tap this icon to display the More menu.

steps.title: Tap Move to.
steps.content: Tap Move to . This option allows you to move the selected files to another location. Alternatively, you can tap Copy to to copy the files to the SD card instead of moving them.

steps.title: Tap SD Card.
steps.content: Tap SD Card . This moves all the selected files to the SD card. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Open the My Files app.
steps.content: Open the My Files app. It has an icon that resembles a yellow folder. It is generally found in the Samsung folder in the Files menu.

steps.title: Tap a category or tap Internal Storage.
steps.content: Tap a category or tap Internal Storage . You can browse files by type, by tapping Video, Images, Audio, Documents, or Downloads at the top of My Files. To browse all folders on your device's internal storage, tap Internal Storage .

steps.title: Navigate to the file(s) you want to transfer.
steps.content: Navigate to the file(s) you want to transfer. Locate the folder that contains the file you want to transfer and tap the folder to open it. [5] X Research source Folders that have an icon that resembles an SD card in the upper-left corner are already stored on the SD card.

steps.title: Tap and hold the file you want to transfer.
steps.content: Tap and hold the file you want to transfer. This displays a checkmark in the upper-left corner of the file. You will also see a blank circle in the left corner of the rest of the files in the folder. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Check all files you want to transfer.
steps.content: Check all files you want to transfer. To check a file, tap the blank circle in the upper-left corner of each file to place a checkmark in the circle.

steps.title: Tap Move.
steps.content: Tap Move . It's the first tab at the bottom of the screen. It has an icon that resembles a folder with an arrow. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Return to the main menu in My Files.
steps.content: Return to the main menu in My Files. To do so, tap the backward navigation button at the bottom of the screen until you return the main menu in My Files. The backward navigation button resembles a bracket pointing left. It's at the bottom of the screen.

steps.title: Tap SD Card.
steps.content: Tap SD Card . This displays all files and folders stored on your SD card. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Tap a folder you want to transfer the select files to.
steps.content: Tap a folder you want to transfer the select files to. Tap the folder to open it. To create a new folder, tap the More menu button ( ⋮ ) in the upper-right corner and then tap Create Folder .

steps.title: Tap Move Here.
steps.content: Tap Move Here . It's the second option at the bottom of the screen. This moves all the selected items to the current folder on the SD card. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Open your Android’s Settings .
steps.content: Open your Android’s Settings . It’s the gear icon typically found in the app drawer. As of Android 6.0 (Marshmallow), you can configure your SD card as part of your internal storage. This makes it so you can download Play Store apps directly to the card. This method involves formatting (erasing) the SD card. You will not be able to take the SD card out and use it in another device (unless you erase all of its data).

steps.title: Scroll down and tap Storage.
steps.content: Scroll down and tap Storage . It's near the bottom of the Storage menu.

steps.title: Select your SD card.
steps.content: Select your SD card. It may be called something like “External Storage” or “SD Card.”

steps.title: Tap ⁝.
steps.content: Tap ⁝ . It’s the three vertical dots at the top-right corner of the screen.

steps.title: Tap Change storage type.
steps.content: Tap Change storage type . This may be called “Storage Settings” on some devices.

steps.title: Tap Format as internal.
steps.content: Tap Format as internal . This formats the SD card so that it can be used to store files on your Android device. This will erase all data currently stored on the SD card.

steps.title: Select a storage option and tap Next.
steps.content: Select a storage option and tap Next . Some devices allow you to choose from two storage options: If you want apps to save their data files (such as the cache) to your SD card in addition to apps, select Use as an internal storage for both apps and data . If you only want apps to be stored on the card, select Use as internal storage for apps only .

steps.title: Tap Erase & Format.
steps.content: Tap Erase & Format . The data on the card will be erased and then set up to allow downloads. You’ll see a confirmation message once the format is complete.

steps.title: Open your Android’s Settings.
steps.content: Open your Android’s Settings . It’s the gear icon typically found in the app drawer. As of the release of Android 6.0 (Marshmallow), it is possible to configure your SD card as part of your internal storage. This makes it possible to download Play Store apps directly to the card. This method involves formatting (erasing) the SD card. Make sure to use a blank card or one you’ve already backed up elsewhere. This method makes it so you cannot take the SD card out and use it in another device (unless you erase all of its data).

steps.title: Scroll down and tap Storage.
steps.content: Scroll down and tap Storage .

steps.title: Select your SD card.
steps.content: Select your SD card. It may be called something like “External Storage” or “SD Card.”

steps.title: Tap ⁝.
steps.content: Tap ⁝ . It’s the three vertical dots at the top-right corner of the screen.

steps.title: Tap Settings.
steps.content: Tap Settings . It's in the menu with three dots in the upper-right corner. This opens the Settings menu.

steps.title: Tap Format as internal.
steps.content: Tap Format as internal . Now you’ll see a warning that lets you know the data on the card will be erased.

steps.title: Tap Erase & Format.
steps.content: Tap Erase & Format . The card will now format as internal storage. Once the card is formatted, apps you download from the Play Store will typically save there by default. Some apps are not able to download to an external card. Such apps will still be installed in the device’s internal storage.

steps.title: Open your Android’s file manager.
steps.content: Open your Android’s file manager. It’s the folder icon labeled something like My Files, File Manager, or Files.

steps.title: Tap the menu ☰ or ⁝.
steps.content: Tap the menu ☰ or ⁝ . It’s the three horizontal lines (or three vertical dots) at the top-right corner of the screen. The menu button varies by device, but you’ll know you’re in the right place if you see a menu that contains a “Settings” option. If you’re using an older Android, tap the menu button on your device.

steps.title: Tap Settings.
steps.content: Tap Settings . It has an icon that resembles a gear.

steps.title: Tap Set home directory.
steps.content: Tap Set home directory . It’s in the main panel under the “Select directories” header.

steps.title: Tap SD Card.
steps.content: Tap SD Card . This may have a different name, such as “extSdCard.”

steps.title: Tap Done.
steps.content: Tap Done . Downloads will now save to your SD card by default.
